item.description:
In this workshop I aim for us to think about how we make and imagine collective places of infrastructure. In this exchange we will materially and technically setup a server space, and along that journey together we will ask questions and discuss how we want to practice these technologies collectively.
The end goal is to have collectively edited set of protocols or a manifesto that we publish to an html page on the server.


Material for this workshop was developed from collaborative work over a number of iterations from projects including servpub, collective infrastructures and cozy-cloud.
Outcomes from this workshop will also be used in my PhD as well as published in the new Servus journal? (I think it is) And I will make sure we are all credited!


This workshop and the server are hosted by Servus in Linx Austria. They are an artist run data centre and have given us this space to practice our own network tech and projects. It is run on hydro electric energy and hosts a number of other collectives, tech enthusiasts and artists.



We will be making and editing a manifesto of sorts as we work through the steps of this workshop.
These will be hosted on an html file on the server, and is accessible at this URL page: https://femfester.in-grid.io/


When it comes to making collaborative community driven sociotechnical infrastructure, there is always a complex network of relations that we have to work through. Negotiating every relation when we enter a space could be very complex and time consuming, as we will see, but setting protocols helps us firm up ways of working and relational conventions that ease this flow. Through setting these protocols together we mean to disobey the norms of network infrastructures and actively re-scope how we come to these systems and relations together.





Relating to original feminist server manifesto by some of Constant. Manifesting and imagining what a feminist server is and does.
A feminist server…  * Is a situated technology. She has a sense of context and considers herself to be part of an ecology of practices * Is run for and by a community that cares enough for h er in order to make her exist * Builds on the materiality of software, hardware and the bodies gathered around it * Opens herself to expose processes, tools, sources, habits, patterns * Does not strive for seamlessness. Talk of transparency too often signals that something is being made invisible * Avoids efficiency, ease-of-use, scalability and immediacy because they can be traps * Knows that networking is actually an awkward, promiscuous and parasitic practice * Is autonomous in the sense that she decides for her own dependencies * Radically questions the conditions for serving and service; experiments with changing client-server relations where she can * Treats network technology as part of a social reality * Wants networks to be mutable and read-write accessible * Does not confuse safety with security * Takes the risk of exposing her insecurity * Tries hard not to apologize when she is sometimes not available


Manifesto = Man x Infest
Infest being the taking hold of and grasping threateningly at things as proof!
Femfester = Feminism x Fistula
Fistula being part of an festering, a pipeline with many holes. Thinking of a patchwork infra!
We can change this, it was just me having fun with wordz.




You can have a lot of passwords and bits here, so I use a password manager like Keypassxc


Lets give a little context of working with computers.


So most people are probably used to working through a graphical user interface (GUI), which is a relatively recent way of interfacing with a computer. This is great for accessibility but also tends to scope and direct the abilities and capacities you have on your computer, as in there are only so many buttons or things you can show in a communicable way.



Terminal is a more classic way of working with a machine, and roughly speaking is the step between punch-card/magnetic tape style computing and a GUI. It is a very simple but powerful interface that lets you run basically any command on your system through a text interface. Compared to a GUI this space is more "risky" as you can do anything from anywhere, such as deleting the entire operating system (not advised). It also means that there are no limitations to your system administration so you have access to a granular level of working.


Prompt When entering into this more "risky" space on a computer network, it is good to set some intentions and work out how to move through this space with care. As we go though these next steps getting into terminal have a think about what it means to be in this place of power/risk, and what relations you think you need to care for in the formation of these protocols? It can also be a great place to think about if/how the relations of a system enables you to perform this role of power, and what change in relations this new role brings with it.


This depends on your platform, so...


On a Mac it is already installed! So all you need to do is:

Search up Terminal
Open it!


There are similar programs to terminal already installed, but not the same language (bash). There are a few ways to do this, but I recomend installing an ubuntu vm shell for bash, as it gives the most capability for this use case:

Install the VM from the windows store HEREand remember your password!
Then open it up!


As we said before terminal is a text/syntax-based way of interfacing your machine and we are going to introduce a few basic commands and concepts to get us going today.


Let's simply use echo to get our terminal to say HI!.
To do this use:
echo <message>
e.g.
echo HI!


Now lets see who your computer!
Show the name of the currently logged in user:
whoami
Show the name of the machine is given on the network:
hostname


Much of working on the command line involves navigating around your system without the use of a Graphical User Interface (GUI).
However, we will essentially be navigating around normal computer folder hierarchies like below:
root/ ├─ directoryname/ ├─ anotherdirectory/ ├─ aFileName.txt

Directory : also known as a folder
Print working directory that you are currently in:
pwd
List current directory contents:
ls


Now to move between directories/folders we use cd like so
cd <directory_name>
e.g.
cd folder1
We can use a folder that was shown with ls in the last step!
You can also check whats in the new folder with ls to see that you have moved.


Prompt In this potentially unfamiliar space how do we keep track of where we are, what we've done & what commands we may need in the future? Basically how do we want to orient ourselves?


Secure Shell (SSH) is a way of working on another machine from your own, working in their shell (bash).
It basically lets you work on another computers terminal remotely. This is the way you will work on most servers or remote/faceless computers (computers without a screen).




The SSH protocol enables us to talk securely to our server by encrypting and authenticating all of our communication/interfacing through the network.
Traditionally tech has a metaphor of SSH as a secure hand shake protocol, but it will be great to think about what metaphor or relation we want when it comes to crossing boundaries and into shared spaces.
Do we want to hand shake or do we think . . . would enable . . .


Again this may be a bit different on different systems, as some will have this already installed and some will need to install it.
Install it with:
sudo apt install openssh-client
If you are on gitbash on windows, it should be installed.


To SSH into the Server with servus we need to use their IP!
An IP address is basically the postcode/address we will find the pi at on the network.
The IP for our Servus server is:
193.170.194.204
But we also have it as a named server:
vps.in-grid.io


Now that we have the IP address, any computer can request to SSH into the server through these commands:
ssh <user_name>@<ip>
eg.
ssh in-grid@193.170.194.204
or
ssh in-grid@vps.in-grid.io
You are now "logging into" our server, so it will ask for the password here and that I will share with you.


You should now see your terminal username change from your laptop's local user to something like:
in-grid@vps:~$
If you want to exit out of the pi (we don't atm) type:
exit
Hit enter. You will need to have exited the pi before setting up your ssh key.


Prompt How do we navigate another machine through our own "interface"?
What are the relational agreements to being on this other machine?


Sudo enables us to take on a superuser role.
This means that we have all the security permissions for that system. This is a "very risky" role, as here you can do anything on the server/computer. With sudo you can actually delete the entire system or make other similar drastic commands, but it also means that we have the ability to manage and configure our system to our needs.
When we come to writing protocols for sudo, what does it mean for us to be a "superuser" or an admin, and what care and consideration should we take on in these protocols?




To become sudo or root you just need to:
sudo su
And then enter the password when prompted.


Prompt Super User can Do! a lot... what permissions are we comfortable navigating?
How intimate are we with our machines?


Caring for a server includes routine tasks like updating/upgrading the system software, tiding up files, creating new users & giving access permissions, paying attention to errors and bug reports.
We are going to initiate this server by making us all users!




To make a new user, use the command below. Note, that you will be prompted to input a password and it is always better to give different users passwords
adduser <nameofuser>


If you want to give this user sudo access, then they have to be added to the "sudo" group. You don't need to create this group, it exists by default and you can just add or remove users from it. The sudo group is stored in this directory: /etc/sudoers.d/
usermod -aG sudo <nameofuser>
You can check to see who is in the group sudo using this command:
grep '^sudo:.*$' /etc/group


Now you can change into the new user (in other words, sign into their account):
su <nameofuser>


You could also log in now with:
ssh <username>@193.170.194.204
or
ssh <username>@vps.in-grid.io
And log in with the password you just added.


Prompt How can we re-imagine users to something less explicit and more gentle?
How do we want to configure the imaginaries to these roles?


SSH Keys are user specific and are used in addition to a shared login password. To make this method of access truly secure we will need to eventually disable password-only login.

The shared password is the Lock, and the private password is the Key. Keys are non-transferable and have to be generated per user.
Make sure you are back on your own system with:
exit
Then to generate the keys, call this command:
ssh-keygen -t rsa
Fill in the information requested (note: most of it is optional so you can leave it blank) and set a password (not optional).


The shared key is the:
id_rsa.pub
and the private Key is the:
id_rsa
Make note of the path to your id_rsa.pub, we'll need it in the next step.


The public, Lock, password now needs to be copied over to the raspberry pi. Do this via this command (replacing the first bracket with the path to the id_rsa.pub, and the second to the Pis IP address, which we found earlier):
ssh-copy-id -i <path to id_rsa.pub> <username>@vps.in-grid.io
Enter password to complete transfer.


I find it easiest to login with the key linked directly.
sudo ssh -i <path/to/id_rsa.pub> <username>@vps.in-grid.io
Note Maybe check you can become sudo with sudo su


Only do this after everyone who need to access the server has uploaded their Keys!
It is also recommended that you keep one person ssh'd in at all times during testing this, so if you do something wrong you can unlock it again.
Access the config file by:
sudo nano -l /etc/ssh/sshd_config

And in uncomment 'PasswordAuthentication' on line 57 and set to 'no', then save and exit:
PasswordAuthentication no
Then restart the SSH connection:
sudo service ssh restart


Keep someone logged in at all times!
Have someone else log out and back in, trying with a password which should fail, and then the key which should work!


Prompt Now this server is "safe" and secure, can we reflect on what that means to us?
How do we imagine this server being a safe space beyond SSH keys?


Tmux is what is called a multiplexer, which is a software that lets us collectively work one terminal session.
This is how many collectives and collaborative networks work together on servers in one space. It lets us edit and run commands in one space and take responsibility and practice our infra becoming together.
When we come to writing protocols we might want to think about what it means to be one user together, and how can we keep everyone at the same pace and comfortable levels of understanding.


All become sudo with:
sudo su
Now we are all sudo we can initiate a shared session to work in together.
To do this we use:
tmux new -s <session name>
e.g.
tmux new -s in-sesh
Now we need to name our collective space. If we think back*forward in this workshop, what are the intentions, dynamics and relations we want to collectively name this space with?


Now we have an active session we can join it by just typing:
tmux a -t in-sesh
Rember we have to be sudo to join this!


Now we can say hi to one another and say cute messages in the space by:
echo <message>
Say something to welcome each other into this session, you may need to take turns.


As we saw even each of us writing an echo command takes a little bit of choreographing. When this gets more complicated, like writing complex configuration files, you can imagine it gets even more tricky.
Prompt So here we need to think about how we might manage collective editing. What operational metaphor might we use to describe the relationship between the person typing and the others? Who and how do we choose to type? How do we take care of every voice in that conversation?


We've created a simple html document to edit. We need to navigate to that file, open and edit it.
First lets navigate to the folder its inside and list its contents.
cd /var/www/femfester ls
We should see a file called:
index.html`


Now we are in the right folder we can edit the file with nano which is a terminal base text editor.
To open the file with nano we do:
nano index.html
This will open the file in the terminal.



Tip Being terminal you have to navigate with the keyboard, and also copy and past by right clicking (not "CNTRL+C/P")


From here we can then add text and images using basic HTML syntax.
For the time being we are going to just add fun bits to see it work, as we have some more protocols to write and add.
So for now add a message or paste in some ascii art with the help of these links:
ascii text gen
ascii image gen
Remember to paste in with a right click!


Now if we return to the file online at:
https://femfester.in-grid.io
we will see our beautiful inputs.


prompt How do we negotiate the space of working collectively as one user?
What other considerations need to be voiced?


When we finish up working together there are lots of things we can do to make it easier to return to our work, make it legible to others, as well as caring for the infrastructure we're working in. This could include careful documentation, understanding how to save and record edits, and exiting programs in their nuanced ways.


We've finished working together and now we would like to leave our TMUX session. This is a little more complex than it might appear. Leaving a session using an 'exit' command will delete the session for others, and you will lose the record of your edits together. Instead we can either:
Close the entire terminal session window, or use Ctrl-b. This will retain the terminal session for you to use again in the future.


Let's consider collectively how to ensure we exit safely, using a door rather than an ejector seat. How does this action differ from exiting other softwares and how does this attention affect our relationships.
prompt How can we form protocols that enable us to care for who is coming next and which


Now we have all the protocols ready lets add them to the HTML file with nano again.
Once we have edited the HTML, we can launch our page in a browser!
At https://femfester.in-grid.io/


Practising infrastructuring collectively can be (intentionally) a slow, careful and unscalable process, so it's important to acknowledge our incremental changes, achievements and presence.


Our (ongoing) documentation

</Practice/In-Grid's In-frastructures/Serving In-grid/

item.title: Improvised Captions
item.description:
This page shares the improvised automated caption setup that was made and shared for the Configure-Able Infrastructures Workshops. Alongside this is also shared here how the different FLOSS video call and automated caption software we tried and that lacked the capacities that was wanted for the workshop.

It does have to be said that even with this desire to manifest FLOSS access, the improvised automated captions we came up with still ended up working with big tech solutions. In discussion we felt working here with google's local automated caption on a FLOSS video call was a way to Wiggle Room towards access within FLOSS. Even though this approach also did ask individuals to configure their own access, we tried to offer up interdependent access through clear instructions, as well as being their to debug issues. This need for collective configuration was also felt to be a place to be in contact with and make sense of automated captioning software.

If you need to use Live Caption here are steps to run them locally on Chrome. This needs you to download the browser to then join the call. Live Caption is only available in English.
On your computer, download and open Chrome.
At the top right, click menu button and then Settings.
At the bottom of the Settings page, click Accessibility.
Turn on Live Caption. Tips:
When you play a video, to turn on captions, at the top right click Media control.
To use Live Captions for videos that auto-play, turn on the video volume.
When you click away from the tab with sound, live captions will appear in a hover-bubble that you can drag. To return to the tab with audio, click.

Here I share the frictions we found with FLOSS video calls when trying to find accessible platforms and ways of meeting through them.



This did have a way of doing live captions, but needed you to set it up from the backend and host Jitsi yourself to do this. We both did not host a Jitsi instance, nor could find one that had this already installed.
After the first workshop, we also realized that Jitsi can only host a small group of people, and the workshop size meant people could not always access the session.


This had room for live captioning (which is great!), but for a workshop like this that lacked the funds to hire a live-captioner, there was no automated option.

Here is a list of addons for Firefox that were also tested out and did not quite work or were not accessible.

https://addons.mozilla.org/en-GB/firefox/addon/auto-subtitle/
https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/live-captioning/idi-p/7548
https://addons.mozilla.org/en-GB/firefox/addon/add-subtitles/
https://addons.mozilla.org/en-GB/firefox/addon/substital/

item.title: In-fra Processing
item.description:
This focus group is to reflect on In-grid's collective organisational methods through a framing of critical access. The focus will be accessible to member's reorientation but it will be a time for us to look back and reflect on how we have started to configure our own infrastructure and background away from big tech institutions and towards feminist and intersectional community infrastructures. In this reflection I hope for us to articulate together through processing our inquiry, a few figures (metaphors) of our own to make accessible these situated relations. To do this we will think through how we have found frictions, or inflexibility when working socially and technically. These will form contours for us to reflect on how we have enabled our collaboration to be Configure-able together. This interplay being the place we form figures and narratives of access from, and where we as a collaboration have flexed towards accessible futures and away from institutional inflexibility .



Go over questions for G
Define together inflexibility and in-flex + qs to help us think through them.
Feel out some topics or experiences to reflect on the inflexibility and then our in-flex-ability.


What are the systematic and institutional relations that hold/held us in place? From Ahmed - lines holding norms of relations in place. + Aimi Hamraie Flexibile users and soft bodies being conformed to hard machines.

Systemic issues around CAPITALISM aside. University structure, jobs/working relationships hold some elements in place, and enable certain actions.
Institutions, these come with some privileges but academia/large institutions can be ableist, smaller grass roots organisations that are not driven by the logics of capitalism can enable alt spaces.
How we stay attached to these institutions or stay with the difficulties of systemic issues, but find wiggle room, how we make wiggle room.
All the other things, like race, class, gender etc etc etc
Social and also contractual relationships
Time = money under the jobbing job world. And collectivising means we can pool time or labour in a time-poor world.
The Catch 22 of being able to prioritise art/research/things that matter for early career researchers/artists/makers is that you already have to have done these things to get the jobs/roles where you are given time for that.
Post-austerity efficiency
What are the things that disable(d) us from doing what we desire(d) in that relation?
Time, space, funding, prestige, brain space, emotional capacity
Dumb systems that's difficult to work with (Ex: No bank options for non- profitable small collective)
Working as a collective, that is not a business or a charity or an institution, makes it difficult to interface with other bodies. Transitioning from a group of individuals to a group that is legally definable?
Right to work, visas etc
wage labour slavery & and chronic health un-diagnosis that both disable/enable my capacity to do anything whether for work or socially, or towrds organising/meeting/ etc
What restrains/ed our capacities relationally and materially?

accountability to each other as a group
defining the boundaries of the group. intimacy / maintaining intimacy (is protecting too intense a word), while balancing openness. Project Grant Funding topics (not for this focus group). Maybe we need to be more strict about who we are inviting in and for how long, what the accountabilities etc
expectations from others in terms of availability/ capacity
What does this friction contour?

Wanting to be open but additionally needing some static for contracts and stuff
Too much admin workload on a few people when having more flexible form/ infrastructure


How do/did we process and feel out that restraint?

Accept what works for the moment and being honest about the solution and the restraint
How did we (want to) flex and wiggle towards our desires?
What did we do to enable us to get close to the space/relation possible that we needed?
How would we have changed or approached this differently?


These don't have to be mutually exclusive, maybe more starting points?



Small tech-ing rather than divesting (cloud dependant). Not an issue with the technology more than how that tech is wielded
clumsiness
no one wants to do the boring stuff for free!!!! aka sysadmin / admin / notes
how to make maintenance a joyful and pleasurable space
tinkering with our own structures can be pleasurable
different social relational boundaries / rules systems of collaborating with other groups / institutions can produce anxiety or suck the joy out of the "boring" stuff
relational boundaries are helpful/healthy. sad as it is capitalist logics give a shorthand for boundaries between service providers and collaborators. without going at the speed of trust it's hard to jump into different relational structures.
big tech smooths the edges of so we are choosing the bumpy edges
inflexibility:
lack of joy as default for maintenance
easy of use - hidden politics
lack of community
frictionless - no way of being in touch with it.
product
convenience in exchange for bad politics
scales can be overwhelming.
Configure-able In-frastructures
interdependence
affective support as well as functional actions . . .
spreading the load of the "inconvenience" of using smaller grass roots cloud service. making room for inconvenience. making visible the labour of maintaining these services.
choosing the scoping of re-clouding. picking collaborators (like servus)



sharing and bringing back knowledge is something many of us are invested in but the inflexibility :
takes a lot of labor
inflexibility

anxiety + relations + penal
lots of work . .
no funding support to do it. . . (unpaid)
needs personnel relations to share
mainly people with mainy things going on
Configure-able In-frastructures
tic, repetitions, small scales of repetitive.
patience and care
not making assumptions that people know whats going on
being generous with time and knowledge.
clarrity
caring about pedagogy
clear refrences
vulnerable


in-flex

Scales of institutional norms
What choices do we have, how to work with resources we can access
Socially relating (differing needs and desires)
how we decide politics and who we align with
capacity for consensus . . . to what extend we delegate decisions or not
CIA's Simple Sabotage Field Manual LOL
Configure-able In-frastructures
Slowing down
love n care n openness
variety in decision making, bespoke decision making, intuition, trust
being okay with being uncomfortable
sedimented trust.
let the chaos reign!!!!




too flex for insti - but a form that fits our needs
three kids in a long coat pretending to be what they expect.


These are very quickly written sum ups, but hope it helps. Do add or edit if you feel they misrepresent or you have q's or other opinions. . .


(Hamraie, 2017) - https://doi.org/10.5749/j.ctt1pwt79d.6.
Writes about the formation of the figure of the user within industrial design and how this was formed from the understanding that human bodies are soft and malleable unlike machines, which are hard, determined and static things humans have to be shaped around. This pulls from a eugenics histories, and also orient ergonomics as a place to shape people as much as it is machines to humans. With critical access here Hamraie questions how we can make room for machines to flex to users instead of this normalising and violent history.

(Cowan & Rault, 2024) - https://punctumbooks.com/titles/heavy-processing/
Talks about bringing queer practices of heavy processing social relations as a way to re-approach the heavy processing needed to start to imagine ethical, de-colonial and anti-abelist technologies. Thinking with it to how In-grid has our own sorts of processing, ones sedimented through relations of trust, in-stability and care.

(Maier et al., 2020) - https://cfshrc.org/article/get-the-frac-in-or-the-fractal-many-festo-a-transcript/
A crip manifesto looking into fractals and repeated patterns as ways to move us beyond the known and into a crip infinite. Here I am highlighting their focus on repetition or a tic we might have, recursively forming actions and relations. . .

(Sarah Ahmed, 2014) - https://feministkilljoys.com/2014/09/28/wiggle-room/
(Pritchard, 2025) - https://titipi.org/wiki/index.php/Wiggleroom
Here thinking about how to reform roles that are pre-figured or sedimented into relations, whether gender, user, disabled, etc. In these thinking how we can collectively wiggle into these spaces, making capacity for the practices we bring with us and desire to be there as well.

(Mingus, 2017) - https://leavingevidence.wordpress.com/2017/04/12/access-intimacy-interdependence-and-disability-justice/
Talking about the need for intimacy in understanding the nuance and care need in access. Here thinking through our expansive intimacies in relation and forming infrastructural access, how we take time, know who might need what, and care for each other to be in that space together.

(Gearty & Marshall, 2021) - https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11213-020-09539-4
This text looks into a reflection on first person action research as a methodology. It looks into how through situated inquiry and one that takes on internal and external arcs of enquiry through both personnel and systemic relations. Here thinking about how we can reflect through these methods to inquire into our own practices internally and externally.

item.title: Intro In-grid
item.description:
In-grid is a trans*feminist collective of artists/educators/technologists working in and around digital infrastructures. In-grid has been working together since 2019, and is made up of a fluid group of people dispersed globally.


This combined panel takes a critical look at digital "cloud" infrastructures. It explores how collectives and communities counter these centralised models through their situated relations, methods and technical practices.
The Combined Panel takes the form of:

A Panel
A workshop <-- We are here
A Hosted Blog <-- We will be posting to here


For the panel we brought together a range of researchers and practitioners. Each panellist shared their nuanced context and how their collectives*communities are making transformations in infrastructures. We did this to see how system admins and community organisers are forming a diversity of nuanced and situated protocols and ways of collaborating otherwise.


Today's workshop aims to bring together the combined panel's conceptual elements with material socio-technical practice. In this session we will enact the creation of a speculative set of protocols that aim to question the relational complexities of editing, updating and maintaining a collective server, and learning some basic technical skills along the way!
The end goal is to have collectively edited set of protocols that we publish to an html page on the server.


The blog element aims to extend conversation from the panel through our own federated infrastructure, subverting and hacking the hierarchies of this conference. It brings this research together in a space that can sit both inside/outside*beyond the conference.
Access it at: ci.servpub.net


We will also be making and editing a set of protocols as we work through the steps of this workshop.
The protocols will be hosted on an html file on the server, and is accessible at this URL page: https://servpub.net/ci_protocols.html


When it comes to making collaborative community driven sociotechnical infrastructure, there is always a complex network of relations that we have to work through. Negotiating every relation when we enter a space could be very complex and time consuming, as we will see, but setting protocols helps us firm up ways of working and relational conventions that ease this flow. Through setting these protocols together we mean to disobey the norms of network infrastructures and actively re-scope how we come to these systems and relations together.





Lets give a little context of working with computers


So most people are probably used to working through a graphical user interface (GUI), which is a relatively recent way of interfacing with a computer. This is great for accessibility but also tends to scope and direct the abilities and capacities you have on your computer, as in there are only so many buttons or things you can show in a communicable way.



Terminal is a more classic way of working with a machine, and roughly speaking is the step between punch-card/magnetic tape style computing and a GUI. It is a very simple but powerful interface that lets you run basically any command on your system through a text interface. Compared to a GUI this space is more "risky" as you can do anything from anywhere, such as deleting the entire hard disc (not advised). It also means that there are no limitations to your system administration so you have access to a granular level of working.


When entering into this more "risky" space on a computer network, it is good to set some intentions and work out how to move through this space with care. As we go though these next steps getting into terminal have a think about what it means to be in this place of power/risk, and what relations you think you need to care for and form protocols for?
It can also be a great place to think about if/how your system let's you into this place of power, and what relations this empowering brings with it.


This depends on your platform, so...


On a Mac it is already installed! So all you need to do is:

Search up Terminal
Open it!


There are similar programs to terminal already installed, but not the same language (bash), so the easiest way to get going is:

Install git Bash from HERE
Then open it up!


As we said before terminal is a text/syntax-based way of interfacing your machine and we are going to introduce a few basic commands and concepts to get us going today.


Let's simply use echo to get our terminal to say HI!.
To do this use:
echo <message>
e.g.
echo HI!


Now lets see who your computer!
Show the name of the currently logged in user:
whoami
Show the name of the machine is given on the network:
hostname


Much of working on the command line involves navigating around your system without the use of a Graphical User Interface (GUI).
However, we will essentially be navigating around normal computer folder hierarchies like below:
root/ ├─ directoryname/ ├─ anotherdirectory/ ├─ aFileName.txt

Directory : also known as a folder
Print working directory that you are currently in:
pwd
List current directory contents:
ls


Now to move between directories/folders we use cd like so
cd <directory_name>
e.g.
cd folder1
We can use a folder that was shown with ls in the last step!
You can also check whats in the new folder with ls to see that you have moved.


Prompt In this unfamiliar space how do we keep track of where we are, what we've done & what commands we may need in the future?
...or any other concerns!


Secure Shell (SSH) is a way of working on another machine from your own, working in their shell (bash).
It basically lets you work on another computers terminal remotely. This is the way you will work on most servers or remote/faceless computers (computers without a screen).




The SSH protocol enables us to talk securely to our server by encrypting and authenticating all of our communication/interfacing through the network.
Traditionally tech has a metaphor of SSH as a secure hand shake protocol, but it will be great to think about what metaphor or relation we want when it comes to crossing boundaries and spaces.
Do we want to hand shake or do we think . . . would enable . . .


Again this may be a bit different on different systems, as some will have this already installed and some will need to install it.
if you are on Mac or Linux you may need to install it with:
sudo apt install openssh-client
If you are on gitbash on windows, it should be installed.


To SSH into the pi we need to know what the IP address of the pi is.
An IP address is basically the postcode/address we will find the pi at on the network.
To do this on the pi we write:
hostname -I
This will print out something like 192.168.0.8, and we need to save this to SSH into the pi


Now that we have the IP address, any computer on that network can request to SSH into the Pi through these commands:
ssh <user_name>@<ip>
eg.
ssh ci@192.168.8.120
You are now "logging into" the pi, so it will ask for the password here and that is . . . . . .


You should now see your terminal username change from your laptop's local user to something like:
ci@servpub~$.
If you want to exit out of the pi (we don't atm) type:
exit
Hit enter. You will need to have exited the pi before setting up your ssh key.


We won't do it here as it takes a minute too long, but to do this securely we would set up a set of keys which, one private and one public, that will do the "hand shake" instead of a less secure password.


Prompt How do we navigate another machine through our own "interface"?
What are the relational agreements to being on this other machine?


Caring for a server includes routine tasks like updating/upgrading the system software, tiding up files, creating new users & giving access permissions, paying attention to errors and bug reports.
Sharing a server space presents the added complexity of doing all of the above with consideration other collectives' and/or groups' pre-existing protocols (eg. Systerserver)




Sudo enables us to take on a superuser role.
This means that we have all the security permissions for that system. This is a "very risky" role, as here you can do anything on the server/computer. With sudo you can actually delete the entire system or make other similar drastic commands, but it also means that we have the ability to manage and configure our system to our needs.
When we come to writing protocols for sudo, what does it mean for us to be a "superuser" or an admin, and what care and consideration should we take on in these protocols?




To become sudo you just need to:
sudo su
And then enter the password when prompted.


Prompt Super User can Do! a lot... what permissions are we comfortable navigating?
How intimate are we with our machines?


Tmux is what is called a multiplexer, which is a software that lets us collectively work one terminal session.
This is how many collectives and collaborative networks work together on servers in one space. It lets us edit and run commands in one space and take responsibility and practice our infra becoming together.
When we come to writing protocols we might want to think about what it means to be one user together, and how can we keep everyone at the same pace and comfortable levels of understanding.


Now we are all sudo we can initiate a shared session to work in together.
To do this we use:
tmux new -s hugs
Now we need to name our collective space. If we think back*forward in this workshop, what are the intentions, dynamics and relations we want to collectively name this space with?


Now we have an active session we can join it by just typing:
tmux a -t hugs
Rember we have to be sudo to join this!


Now we can say hi to one another and say cute messages in the space by:
echo <message>
Say something to welcome each other into this session, you may need to take turns.


As we saw even each of us writing an echo command takes a little bit of choreographing. When this gets more complicated, like writing complex configuration files, you can imagine it gets even more tricky.
So here we need to think about how we might manage collective editing. What operational metaphor might we use to describe the relationship between the person typing and the others? Who and how do we choose to type? How do we take care of every voice in that conversation?


We've created a simple html document to edit. We need to navigate to that file, open and edit it.
First lets navigate to the folder its inside and list its contents.
cd /var/www/pubdoc ls
We should see a file called:
ci_protocols.html


Now we are in the right folder we can edit the file with nano which is a terminal base text editor.
To open the file with nano we do:
nano ci_protocols.html
This will open the file in the terminal.



Tip Being terminal you have to navigate with the keyboard, and also copy and past by right clicking (not "CNTRL+C/P")


From here we can then add text and images using basic HTML syntax.
So for now add a message or paste in some ascii art with the help of these links:
ascii text gen
ascii image gen


Now if we return to the file online at:
https://servpub.net/ci_protocols.html
we will see our beautiful inputs.




When we finish up working together there are lots of things we can do to make it easier to return to our work, make it legible to others, as well as caring for the infrastructure we're working in. This could include careful documentation, understanding how to save and record edits, and exiting programs in their nuanced ways.


We've finished working together and now we would like to leave our TMUX session. This is a little more complex than it might appear. Leaving a session using an 'exit' command will delete the session for others, and you will lose the record of your edits together. Instead we can either:
Close the entire terminal session window, or use Ctrl-b. This will retain the terminal session for you to use again in the future.


Let's consider collectively how to ensure we exit safely, using a door rather than an ejector seat. How does this action differ from exiting other softwares and how does this attention affect our relationships.


prompt How do we negotiate the space of working collectively as one user?
What other considerations need to be voiced?


Now we have all the protocols ready lets add them to the HTML file with nano again.
Once we have edited the HTML, we can launch our page in a browser!
At https://servpub.net/ci_protocols.html


Practising infrastructuring collectively can be (intentionally) a slow, careful and unscalable process, so it's important to acknowledge our incremental changes, achievements and presence.




Our (ongoing) documentation https://github.com/In-grid-collective/servPubWiki.git

Small board computer (SBC)

Peripherals
HDMI, screen, keyboard, mouse etc.
A laptop or other personal computer

00.1 Network terminology

00.2 Terminal Unix Commands Cheat Sheet
Is an introduction to working on the command line.

In-grid has tried to make these docs accessible and legible (as possible) to both technical and non-technical reading. We have done this through not only try to follow the Web Content Access Guidelines but also working with the concept of semi-plain language that Kelsie Acton notes in here chapter Plain Language for Disability Culture in Crip Authorship. Acton states this as:
Note on writing: This chapter is written in what I call a semi- plain language style. This means I do the following:
Use an active voice
Mostly use the 6000 most common words in the English language
Use short sentences
Use 14 point font
Use “I” and “you”
Following Acton, In-grid understands this as not trying to assimilate dialogues into dominant technical talking points, but we approach this practice through critical access to distribute and share the expertise of systems and make the disputable from many backgrounds and knowledges.
In-grid also approaches this as a place of design friction. This is where we have made room within and around these hard network infrastructures with and for our softer practices of collective access. In this space of semi-plain In-grid have iterated our own attempt at semi-plain technical docs!
We may also use "us" and "we" to state In-grid and Servpub collaborators who made this infrastructure.

item.description:
This Femfester is In-grid’s iteration of the feminist server manifesto. As we rub up against and dance our way into network practices, a festering acts as a place to form intentions and imagine how we want to collectively meet here. We fester as we care for the holes in our pipelines, tend to the ooze that undulates out and sit with these leaky seamful infrastructures. We don't aim to cure these frictions or plug these holes, but to care for them. We ask how we can enable infrastructuring to fester otherwise from our pulsating practices?

A femfestering Server . . . . . - Is a situated technology. The server feels out their context and considers themselves to be part of an ecology of practices. - Is maintained by a community that cares enough for the frictions of accessing and maintaining a server, and where these frictions feel like a generative affair. - Ferments the materiality of software, hardware and the relations of the bodies gathered around them. - Opens themselves to expose the difficult processes, tools, sources, habits and patterns to make accessible these difficulties. - Does not strive for seamlessness, as it creates a bubble. Talk of transparency too often signals that something is being made invisible and inaccessible. - Avoids efficiency, ease-of-use, scalability and immediacy because they can be cages we need to abolish. - Knows that networking is actually an awkward, promiscuous, interdependent and pleasurable practice. - Is autonomous in that they feel out their own dependencies, relations and politics. - Radically questions the conditions for serving and service; practices queering client-server relations where they can. - Approaches network technology and sociotechnical systems as places of social change. - Enables networks and their practices to be improvise-able and read-write accessible. - Does not confuse safety with security. - Takes the risk of exposing their insecurity. - Tries hard not to apologies when they are not available, as they learn to communicate their capacities.

item.title: Glossary
item.description:
This Glossary shares some of the key terms and words used to shape this research. These descriptions aim to accessibly offer up how this research works with crip and queer feminist theory to form critical access informed approaches to community infrastructuring. These terms help to understand how this research makes sense of the many bodies, technologies and relations that it is in touch with. The glossary is not complete or totalizing; rather, it traces words and concepts I have oriented with to bring together, move through, and make friction with the unknowable and unpredictable actions of community infrastructuring.
The references for these terms can be found on the repo's References page.


Misfitting is a situated methodology of caring for how people and their communities want to be oriented politically and materially, and attending to how these desires misfit within the determinate slots of institutions and infrastructures. Misfitting as a method makes space for bodies to (dis)orient infrastructures, relations and politics through their ambivalent relationships and embodied expertise to these systems. As a situated process, misfitting animates systems from their localities and shapes complex systems and knowing from emergent actions instead of set plans.
(Garland-Thomson 2011)
(Rice et al. 2024)


Friction is a process of access making. Friction arises both from the feeling of misfitting, and the ways that crip and queer bodies make sense of what barriers exist, as well as making access through friction, making disorienting requests, improvising infrastructures and transforming these feelings into change. In crip theory, friction rubs up against itself through wordplay; there can be pain from frictions, but there is also a possibility for pleasure and joy, which is often never imagined. Friction in this research is a place of joyous, pleasurable and embodied access making in action that also makes room for and validates its awkward and painful processes.
(Kafer 2013)
(Hamraie and Fritsch 2019)
(Hamraie 2023)


Wiggle room emerges from friction making around the categories and relations that people are prescribed by the norms of systems. People and communities make wiggle room together by feeling out how these determined categories and relations misfit the bodyminds they enclose and creating space through friction for relations that affirm their lives and desired orientations.
(Ahmed 2014)
(Pritchard 2022)


The Table is a metaphor for the institutional norms that have been gradually sedimented into determined and inflexible relations. Tables in this research take many forms, from my desk, to excell tables, to kitchen tables, to interview tables, and to operating tables. This research asks how these tables and their sedimented norms put limits on how we can be together in relation. In theory and practice, this thesis considers how we can start to wiggle room to disorient these tables to affirm our lives, community relations, practices and politics.
(Ahmed 2006)
(Suchman 2012)


The Crip Table imagines what a table shaped by crip politics and community might feel like. The crip table makes room to imagine how systems, infrastructures and their inflexible relations can be flexible to and shaped by the bodyminds they misfit and cause friction with towards indeterminate relations of life affirmation, community desire, and justice.
(Mingus 2017)
(Kafai 2021)
(Kafer 2023)
(Simms and Marangoni 2025)


The Bodily Horizon situates how bodies are in relation with the things around them. The Bodily Horizon makes room to question what is within reach, what can be changed, and what limits and capacities there are within the actions we take. It makes sense of the frictions of the present while also questioning how bodies desire to be oriented towards futures, and what they desire to be within reach. The Bodily Horizon comes from a body in motion, one that feels and makes change between the present and the future.
(Ahmed 2006)


In crip theory, the Bodymind is the refusal of the split between mind and body made within Western medicine and philosophy. The bodymind is a place of feeling, sense- and knowledge-making. In breaking down boundaries between mind and body, this research is also intimate with the boundaries between bodies and the relations that impact or misfit them. By questioning the determined ways bodies, minds and their matters are separated, this research considers how relations can be transformed through entangled and distributed sense-making and expertise.
(Clare 2017)
(Schalk 2018)


This research makes-sense through embodied practices that are situated within the social, relational and emotional context of the those bodyminds misfitting within configurations. By making-sense in this research I bring in the backgrounded knowledges and expertise of systems that offer up a plurality of narratives, perspectives and practices that can disorient the normalized and isolated plans of systems. In this approach I work with creative, discursive and textural inquiries that shape systems through the processes and practices that are accessible and make-sense to those manifesting them.
(Marshall 1999)
(Marshall 2004)
(Gearty and Marshall 2021)
(Pritchard et al. 2021)

item.title: Disobedient Action Research Methods
item.description:
The indeterminate diagram above represents this project's disobedient methodology as it aims to (dis)orient the standardized and prescribed methods of configuration. Each time you visit this page, and every time you click on the diagram, it creates a different composition of actions, sense makings and wiggling of room that this disobedient crip methodology entices. Visually it forms loops and cycles of the icons and terms of this research connected into indeterminate compositions. Each iteration has a generated Alt-text containing the syntax for the diagram, and which can be interpreted in a similarly playful way. The Alt-text is attached to the <div> with the .mermaid class.
This code is an edit of another work/performance called Pad2Party that Sunni Liao, Yewen Jin and I made as part or RealBodies 2.1 with In-grid collective.


For this project I have taken on a Disobedient Action Research Methodology. As the above texture and indeterminate diagram tries to highlight, this methodology disobediently refuses to be generalized or normalized into set operations. Instead this project's Trans*methods make wiggle room for bodyminds to access, be in touch with and shape the sociotechnical infrastructures and matters they are impacted by and misfit within.
To build up my projects Disobedient Action Research methodology I work with the debugging methods of TiTIPi (Pritchard et al., 2021) and build it up with misfitting methods of Carla Rice et al. (2024) to ask what room can collective embodied inquiries make within infrastructuring. With this methodology I make room to be intimate with and build up collective expertise that question what affirmative infrastructures, practices and relations are within reach socially and technically through independent action. Through this disobedient methodology I re-frame what actions can be taken within academic research, moving to make-sense of what lives are livable beyond assimilation norms of access, organization and infrastructures on institutional terms.
Through my Trans*methodology my research is shaped through collective practices, debugging, terminal consoles, bank interfaces, parties, workshops, messaging stickers, VPN's and soft cushions. Coalescing together these many surfaces, textures and tables of research collaborators and I made sense of how our technical practices could be shaped by our backgrounds, expertise and feelings. Through this methodology collectively figuring out what our affirmative community infrastructures are through unfolding actions of access making.


These protocols offer up some of the ways my disobedient methods have unfolded within this research project. These protocols themselves are loose mappings of what happened in this research and offers up how these methods are improvisable, situated, and shaped by their actions.


Practicing Protocols shares how these methods unfolded into a set of accessible workshops that questioned the configurations of network infrastructures. These workshops made wiggle room for people to make sense of and shape network infrastructures through their embodied expertise and situated practices.
This protocol unfolded from the Collective Infrastructures combined panel, and at the Serving In-grid workshop. These workshop inquiries made wiggle room for us to unfold collective expertise around our misfitting within the normalized network configurations we have inherited. From misfitting moving to form counter figures, relations and imaginaries for the affirming network infrastructures we desire now.

This mapping above gives shape to how this protocol took action. It moves from accessible technical documentation that helped us make sense of our embodied misfitting within these configurations. From this misfitting forming our own situated figures and terms for how we want to practice this infrastructure locally.


Improvising Floss Protocols shares how these methods unfolded around making access within FLOSS technologies throughout this research. This protocol offers up how collaborators and I wiggled room between the misfitting of FLOSS and our access knowledges to improvise our own access technologies. Through these practices of access making, making sense of the limits and capacities of access within FLOSS.
This protocol unfolded from the the Configure-Able Infrastructures Workshop I organised with NEoN digital, making the Cozy-ish and Cozy Night and Day themes, as well as manifesting the Cozy-Intentions and Serving Cozy install. This protocol unfolded from the wiggled room made within FLOSS technologies for them to be shaped by and affirm our access knowledges, practices and desires.

This mapping above gives shape to how this protocol made sense of how FLOSS technologies we had in reach misfitted with the access knowledges and practices of the group. From this misfitting moving to wiggle room, improvise and shape the imaginaries and capacities of FLOSS through collective practices of access making.


(Dis)orienting Protocols shares how these methods unfolded when being in touch with and disobediently trying to shape institutional configurations and organization processes. This protocol offers up how collaborators and I made wiggle room around inflexible institutional norms to (dis)orient them towards our backgrounds, politics and desires for the future.
This protocol unfolded from collaborating on In-grid's organizational practices that are shared in the In-fra Processing entry. The protocol was also shaped by the Disobedient Access Requests that I made towards the Tate's configurations and within En-crip-ing Time's refusal of the configurations of network time and intimacies.

This mapping above gives shape to how this protocol (dis)oriented configurations by making wiggle room to feel out our frictions with the sedimented norms of institutions and their organization. From this wiggle room starting to unfold and form our own organizational practices, desires and imaginaries for how we want to orient and improvise them locally.

item.title: In-Grid's In-frastructures
item.description:
These inquiries offer up how critical access can be brought into collaborations within non-disabled centered communities, not as extra time, but as a way to Wiggle Room within infrastructuring practices for interdependent sense making and collective action. These inquiries aim to share how critical access practices and methods make room for a collective like In-grid to question our organizational and network infrastructures by both coming into contact with them, but also by shaping them from our backgrounds and expertise. In this inquiry, especially bring focus to how critical access practices made room for our misfitting within normalizing configurations to unfold into counter expertise and knowledges. With this approach making-sense of the assimilationist norms and politics of network and organizational configuration in a way that where we could refuse, improvise and deviate from the norms we felt friction with.

In this session, questioning how misfit within and made friction around the social and institutional inflexibilities our collective were impacted by when trying to organize together.

In these collective practices questioning how prescribed technical configurations and their isolated expertise can be disputed, improvised and refused when made accessible to other backgrounds, capacities and knowledges.

item.title: Serving In-grid
item.description:
This second iteration of the Practising Protocols workshop was run in-ternally with In-grid members. In this session we set up our Virtual Private Server (VPS) that is hosted with Servus. This aims to be an experimental server for us to test and make sense of our network infrastructuring practices. In the workshop we made room to figure out how we wanted to imagine and enact our infrastructure as we configured it. In this process both aiming to make the VPS and its technical practices accessible to members of In-grid, but in doing so making room to (dis)orient and care for the misfitting of these technical practices by bringing them in touch with our collective background and embodied expertise.
From this workshop, In-grid manifested our experimental VPS to be encoded through our own counter figures. These ranged from refusing the role of Users to instead be carers, maintainers, players, personas and collaborators. It also made room for us to come into contact with and make sense of the many layers of network security these technologies are kept "safe" through. In response to this sense-making of misfitting forming our own dialogues around how we imagine networks becoming safe through trust, care and intimacy. From manifesting our configure-able VPS infrastructure, we also turned to form our own manifesto for it, called the Femfester (In-grid et al., 2024), and which was published with Servus in the first edition of their Artists Running Datacentres journal.

item.title: En-crip-ing Time
item.description:
This entry shares En-crip-ing time, which is a crip infrastructure made in collaboration with Mariana Marangoni. With En-crip-ing time we made room for crip time in network time, now and in the future. Through this we questioned the intimacies and care needed to not only manifest, but maintain crip infrastructures like these. This work was presented at Mesh Festival, as well as an essay about it published with Brand-New-Life Journal.
The En-crip-ing time infrastructure is run on the Cozy-Cloud server as a way to crip the internal clock and background of the server. It does this by poetically cripping the cron jobs (deterministic maintenance jobs) of the server to be chronic jobs (indeterminate, indefinite and intimate care). In this creative inquiry making room for Mariana and I to make sense of our misfitting within the configurations of network time, to then imagine how we want to poetically hack it now to imagine crips beyond its limits.



This entry share the live work that can be accessed online. This work is constantly changing shape and form so each time you visit it, it will perform another iteration of the En-crip-ed poem.


This entry shares the published essay around the work. It aims to bring together an accessible understanding of the technical steps needed to remake the work on your system, alongside the theoretical and conceptual ideas we have threaded throughout the piece.

item.title: Cozy-Intentions
item.description:
This page brings together the cozy intentions for the cozy-cloud.net. This is to give an understanding of how and why this crip server came to be and to share some of the desires we have when making an affirmative digital space that orients from disabled people, affirming politics and embodied expertise.
These intentions take the format of image and alt text pairs, each pair offering up their own thread to be followed, weaving together a story that figures out the cozy-cloud. In a crip move, these intentions entangle together the affective sense making and their knowledges, within political and relational imaginaries that aim to transform the capacities and imaginaries of sociotechnical infrastructures.
Working poetically with Alt texts these intentions emphasis how access practices have the capacity to be joyful, fun and cozy, not the determinate awkward and painful tasks they are often made out to be.
These intentions ask: If we as disabled x neurodiverse x chronically ill people have the capacity to shape digital infrastructure and the ways our communities meet online from our backgrounds and embodied expertise, what could that be and feel like?




Furry text saying "Let's Get Cozy", welcomes you to get cozy! This is an enthusiastic and loving message reminding you to get cozy in which ever way you desire to.
Many times (not always) when we can't get cozy, our sense making of misfitting here is telling us that something might be wrong systemically. This text asks us to think, what would make room for me to get cozy? What relations would have to change for me to actually be cozy? By trying to get cozy you start to make these transformations, so settle in and lets get cozy.




A cloud sits unsure on a day with mixed weather. It feels sensitive to the gusts and gales of bigger clouds and so searches for a sheltered valley to get cozy and come back to earth.
It asks us to think about how we feel in the cloud. When we are using cloud enabled devices, like streaming, cloud drives or social platforms do we feel a connection to what it is we are doing? What would it feel like to be in touch and get cozy with our digital infrastructures.




The cozy-cloud sits within a ring of furry and cozy text saying "Less Cloud - More Cozy". It feels warmth in knowing its energies are conserved for doing cozy things and not being a part of deadly storms elsewhere.
It asks us to think about less dispersion of our digital selves into a commercial cloud that displaces the harms of digital infrastructures out of reach. How can we settle in, keep ourselves close and feel out how cozy our clouds could be?




Slightly clumsy but cute furry text says "Clouds are finite :( Coziness can be infinite!". It sits slightly slumped to one side, exhausted with keeping up with the continuous expansion.
It helps us to reflect on the limitations of computing and cloud infrastructures, the consumption of fossil fuels, rare minerals and people's labor to try to maintain the unmaintainable infinite growth. What if we center our clouds on other infinities of care, compassion and coziness? What would network infrastructures feel like and have the capacity for through these more intimate modes?




A map of arpnet, an early computer network produced by the us gov/army is transformed into a cozy-constellation. This transformation resembles the way digital networks have a history of control of space (both physical and virtual) through force and how we have to transform them with care and coziness.
It asks us how we could imagine networks in retreat from these histories of mapping, taxonomy and capture to instead feel out what their affirmative promise could be when embracing coziness.




A png of a cloud with transparent background so that it appears comfortable and confident wherever it is displayed. The cloud presents so light and pretty floating on the page, but still on the edge of creating a little drizzle. The image itself is on a free license so is free like a cloud!
It reminds us what a cloud looks like and what it has capacity for. The computational infrastructures that make up the commercial cloud could never be so light nor caring to our ecology and body/minds. What metaphors or analogies do you desire our network infrastructures to be performed through? How would you transform and shape them by putting these infrastructure in your own terms.

</Practice/Cozy-Cloud/

item.title: Configure-Able Infrastructures Workshop
item.description:
These collaborative workshops were organized with NEoN digital to share some queer, feminist and crip practices towards network infrastructures. In these workshops I collaborated with MELT and members of SysterServer to run two workshops and share how collective access can be understood and actioned within digital networks.
Due to a desire to run these workshops online and through Free Libre Open Source Softwar (FLOSS) these workshops also offered up a number of misfittings around how FLOSS imagines and makes room for accessibility. This came from the realization that in the context of this workshop where we needed automated captions, there were no easily accessible FLOSS softwares that could meet these requirements. From this misfitting we emerged an understanding of how FLOSS does not make room or time for accessibility, neither does it imagine it as essential.
From this friction the workshop also made Wiggle Room to improvise and hack together an automated live captioning setup that made room for everyone to meet through FLOSS online, but also for people to setup their own local live captioning software on their computer if they wanted it. This improvised setup even though being on individuals computers was intentionally felt out and actioned through collective sense making and interdependent action.

item.title: Disobedient Action Research Methods
item.description:
The indeterminate diagram above represents this project's disobedient methodology as it aims to (dis)orient the standardized and prescribed methods of configuration. Each time you visit this page, and every time you click on the diagram, it creates a different composition of actions, sense makings and wiggling of room that this disobedient crip methodology entices. Visually it forms loops and cycles of the icons and terms of this research connected into indeterminate compositions. Each iteration has a generated Alt-text containing the syntax for the diagram, and which can be interpreted in a similarly playful way. The Alt-text is attached to the <div> with the .mermaid class.
This code is an edit of another work/performance called Pad2Party that Sunni Liao, Yewen Jin and I made as part or RealBodies 2.1 with In-grid collective.


For this project I have taken on a Disobedient Action Research Methodology. As the above texture and indeterminate diagram tries to highlight, this methodology disobediently refuses to be generalized or normalized into set operations. Instead this project's Trans*methods make wiggle room for bodyminds to access, be in touch with and shape the sociotechnical infrastructures and matters they are impacted by and misfit within.
To build up my projects Disobedient Action Research methodology I work with the debugging methods of TiTIPi (Pritchard et al., 2021) and build it up with misfitting methods of Carla Rice et al. (2024) to ask what room can collective embodied inquiries make within infrastructuring. With this methodology I make room to be intimate with and build up collective expertise that question what affirmative infrastructures, practices and relations are within reach socially and technically through independent action. Through this disobedient methodology I re-frame what actions can be taken within academic research, moving to make-sense of what lives are livable beyond assimilation norms of access, organization and infrastructures on institutional terms.
Through my Trans*methodology my research is shaped through collective practices, debugging, terminal consoles, bank interfaces, parties, workshops, messaging stickers, VPN's and soft cushions. Coalescing together these many surfaces, textures and tables of research collaborators and I made sense of how our technical practices could be shaped by our backgrounds, expertise and feelings. Through this methodology collectively figuring out what our affirmative community infrastructures are through unfolding actions of access making.


These protocols offer up some of the ways my disobedient methods have unfolded within this research project. These protocols themselves are loose mappings of what happened in this research and offers up how these methods are improvisable, situated, and shaped by their actions.

item.title: Configure-Able Infrastructures
item.description:
This repo shares the methods and practice that unfolded from the "Configure-able Infrastructures" research project. This research offers up how critical access informed practices made wiggle room for our embodied expertise of misfitting to shape our collective organizing and infrastructuring. Through these methods and practices making accessible the technologies that support us, so that we can challenge and (dis)orient the normalizing configurations, relations and politics we have inherited with them.


This research project engages crip and queer methods to experimentally and collectively (dis)orient the norms and limits of network infrastructure towards more life-affirming possibilities. Building on feminist Science and Technology Studies (STS) (Suchman 2012; Amoore 2020), the thesis interrogates the deterministic configurations, prescribed roles and relations that hold organizational and network infrastructures in place, while taking up crip and queer methods to further examine how such infrastructures create hard systems that reinforce ableist conceptions of use, access, and knowledge. Through the disobedient methods, practices and politics offered by Disability Justice, crip and queer theory (Ahmed 2006; Kafer 2013; 2023; Hamraie 2017; 2023; Rice et al. 2024), I question the inherited figures of configuration (such as “users”) and develop alternative ways of manifesting systems that are people-powered and center the needs of collectives instead of configuring people into infrastructural elements. Combining critique with practice, the thesis generates collective methods for making wiggle room (Ahmed 2014; Pritchard 2022) in network infrastructures for soft, situated, indeterminate, and misfitting embodied knowledges and emergent forms of collective life.
My research undertakes three inquiries into what configure-able infrastructures can be in action. Rather than abstract systems, these collective infrastructuring practices are situated, shaped, and manifested by specific contexts and bodies. In the first inquiry, I reflect on my practices and experiences of access making, examining how the misfitting of collective access and access riders can shape configurations from sites of friction. The second inquiry is grounded in collaboration with In-grid collective, a Trans*Feminist digital arts collective, exploring how critical access can inform collective intersectional practice from the outset, instead of being added on afterward. The final inquiry manifests crip network infrastructures by and for disabled people through work on the Cozy-Cloud, a crip server and collaborative practice. By making room for disabled people to form their own expertise, practices and knowledge of network infrastructures, it becomes possible to disorient the sedimented configurations of hard technical systems, and to form counter configure-able infrastructures that unfold from embodied knowledges, experiences and collective practices.
From these inquiries, the thesis offers methods and practices for disorienting the normative configurations of infrastructures through crip and queer forms of “misfitting” when accessing and using these systems, and the collective sense-making that unfolds. By making wiggle room around misfitting, this research not only validates but builds from the embodied knowing and frictious expertise of systems. These inquiries share how collaborators and I have started to make room for our own configure-able infrastructures through interdependent practices of access making and knowing.
This thesis does not offer solutions or cures to the misfitting of network infrastructures, collective organizing and their configurational methods, but surfaces how crip and queer methods can make room for the frictions of misfitting expertise and practices that can take them off course, and towards the affirming futures we desire now.

item.title: Cozy Night and Day
item.description:
This entry shares the current theme for the Cozy-Cloud website, which works with Bludit CMS. It is made to be very light weight so that those with limited connection and unstable internet networks can still access the site. The theme also utilizes tags/code to activate Screen Readers and which make the information of the website much more accessible to those who use assistive tools to view online media.
This website and theme make room to bring together the work of the Cozy-Cloud by offering up lightweight and accessible introductions to each work and infrastructure. It is also a move towards building up the capacities of the Cozy-Cloud so that it can be accessible to more collaborations and exchanges through this more accessible CMS.



This entry shares the git for the theme for the website so that it can be used by others and potentially be edited from into other iterations. It is a minimal and fairly accessible theme to set up and edit.

item.title: Cozy-Cloud
item.description:
These inquiries offer up how the Cozy-Cloud made wiggle room for a crip server and network infrastructuring practices to unfold emergent actions of access making. Through these actions making sense of the misfitting between the politics and practices of disability justice and those sedimented within network configurations. These inquiries take the form of solo and collaborative action research and creative technical practices of access making. These works were presented at Mesh Festival and published in Brand-New-Life journal as well as informed by a residency at the BDFI.
These inquiries question how we came together through crip intimacies and access practices to make-sense of the misfitting that we felt within the prescribed configurations of network infrastructures. By wiggling room for these frictions we independently figured out what life affirming network infrastructures, practices and relations we desired within and beyond these systems. In this approach bringing focus to how disabled experiences, embodied expertise and independent practices offer up an ambivalent relationship to infrastructures that can (dis)orient the normalizing network configurations towards ones that are shaped by the bodyminds they impact and misfit.



This entry shares the cozy installation and relaxation space for the Cozy-Cloud. It brings together the soft cozy-cloud cushions, the easy read cozy intentions and the tactile server base.


This entry shares the first theme for the Cozy-Cloud's website. Working with Pico, this light weight and (somewhat) accessible blog hosted the server's original Cozy-Intention.


This entry shares the cozy intentions for the cozy-cloud. These intentions both shape the promise and orientation of this crip network infrastructure. In their medium these intentions also offer up how Alt texts and network access practices can make room to imagine this infrastructure through care, joy and creativity.


This entry shares the crip infrastructure made in collaboration with Mariana Marangoni called En-crip-ing Time. This infrastructure crips the Cozy-Cloud server's clock and manifests poetic server protocols that offer up how networks might be (dis)oriented through crip time and intimate maintenance practices.


This entry shares the latest theme for the Cozy-Cloud blog and which focuses on being much more accessible. This was to try to make it more accessible to collaborations, but also for the content to be picked up more clearly by screen readers and access technologies.

item.title: In-Docs
item.description:
These docs unfolded from In-grid's collaboration during the Servpub project. These docs were made during the infrastructuring process to help us share and explain how to setup the back-end VPN and server infrastructure with collaborators. Through this process we questioned how the norms of docs and of sharing technical knowledge were encoded and formatted to be only accessible by certain bodies, backgrounds and knowledges. From our sense making of misfitting within these norms, we started to question how we desired to overcome these barriers through collective access making.
To counter the barriers of access within these docs and technical network practices we were informed through Kelsie Acton's framing of Plain Language For Disability. Through Acton's understanding and approach to plain language we began to question how technical language can start to move towards a plain language version. This version making room within these technical norms not only for people to access and make sense of them in action, but for their sedimented norms to be disoriented and manifested from a plurality of embodied expertise and backgrounds.
It also has to be said that these docs are not "Plain Language" in the sense that Acton's work would present it, but are instead a step towards plain language from technical docs. In this motion, similarly this was also a place to start to inform In-grid (a majority non-disabled collective) to be informed by and in touch with critical access practices and discourse. So even though these docs are not the most accessible plain language, they do describe this first contact and movement towards more accessible and disputable technical discourse within In-grid.



This entry shares a snapshot of the intro page of the accessible technical Docs In-grid put together. It links out to the rest of the Docs online, but also offers up our notes on making more accessible docs and being inform by Kelsie Acton's Plain Language
